ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: 1 hour of reading each week and about 5 hours for each small assignment
I spent less than three hours a week doing readings. However, I spent more time doing assignments, projects, and studying for the final exam.
On an average week, about 1, but when we had assignments, more, and for the paper many hours.
5-8 hours
5 hours/week

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: The course's biggest strength is its instructor, Brenda Cartmel. However, I unfortunately feel that because cancer epi is such a broad topic, I am walking away from the semester with fairly superficial knowledge. It would be great to see this course with a structure perhaps similar to nutrition, where students had a weekly discussion section.

This course provided a wonderful overview of cancer epidemiolgoy. The use of guest lecturers provided perspectives from professionals in different fields, which was very useful. Cancer epidemiology is too broad to be covered in one course alone, but this class did as well as it could to cover the most relevant topics. Absolutely excellent.
Great course. A very good overview to cancer for people unfamiliar with the topic.

This was a good course. I really liked the "survey" nature of the course, with many different lecturers/topics each week of the semester. I think it might be helpful to tie in the guest lectures a little bit so there is more consistency throughout the course - perhaps a standard structure/template for presentations and/or having a *brief* weekly homework assignment (1-3 questions) about topics to ensure that students get similar outcomes from each lecture.

I enjoyed this course. There is a lot to be learned about the etiology, diagnosis, risk factors of cancer. Though I have a background in cancer epidemiology, I liked that this class focused on several major risk factors and cancers that are public health concern. I thought he guest lecturers were great and I liked that the professor supplemented each guest lecture with her own. My one dislike is that all the power points are different. Some are hard to look back on and understand what was trying to be conveyed. Also, assignments were lengthy at times and was more work than I thought it would be.

The course covers a lot of material, and packs a lot into the semester. Guest speakers spoke to us about their area of expertise in cancer, and most of them were great.During the afternoon time slot, I find it harder to stay awake, so it would be nice if the instructors involved the class more in their presentations.
the course is very informational, well-organized.

The course gave me an excellent overview of all cancer sites, including pathology, measurement/definitions, and epidemiology. The course is unique in that most lectures are taught by visiting lecturers. This component is fantastic in that it allows a unique insight into a cancer site by an expert in that specific field. The downside of this is that each lecturer is not equally engaging or informative as a lecturer. Overall, I feel the guest lectures were a positive to the course, and we were very lucky to have them.
The subject material is very interesting, but some of the lectures could have gone a little more in depth.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Brenda Cartmel  Dr. Cartmel is an extremely kind and knowledgeable instructor. I felt very comfortable approaching her with questions.
Instructor: Brenda Cartmel  Dr. Cartmel is knowledgable, approachable, and experienced. Her lecture style is quite personal and fits perfectly with this course.

Instructor: Brenda Cartmel  Amazing professor! She is so nice and so knowledgeable. I wanted to do a topic for my class presentation that wasn't directly related to the topic and she was willing to be flexible and work with me so I was able to develop my interests and apply them to cancer.
Instructor: Brenda Cartmel  Dr. Cartmel was good at helping us understand how to approach cancer epidemiology topics.
Instructor: Brenda Cartmel  very good instructor; super knowledgeable and helpful
Instructor: Brenda Cartmel  Dr. Cartmel was a pleasure to learn from. I think she is very nice and her enthusiasm for the course materials made it very enjoyable.
Instructor: Brenda Cartmel  The instructor is very friendly, interested in the students, and organized.
Instructor: Brenda Cartmel  Dr. Cartmel makes sure we all learn something out of the course.
Instructor: Brenda Cartmel  Dr. Cartmel is very knowledgeable and has structured a very comprehensive cancer epidemiology course.
Instructor: Brenda Cartmel  I really liked how she brought in guest lecturers who are experts in the topics that we were discussing

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: A basic review course on topics in cancer epidemiology.
I would highly recommend this course. Cancer mortality is second only to cardiovascular disease in the US, making it an important topic for all epidemiologists.
Great introductory course for people who want to learn more about cancer.
This was a good course for students who want a broad introduction to cancer epidemiology topics.
you should take it!

This course is an introduction to cancer epidemiology that covers all all things related to understanding the cancer in relation to public health. It is a great background course for those interested in cancer epidemiology.
It is a great overview of the epidemiology of cancer. Yes
I would recommend it to another student if they are interested to know more about cancers. It is very informational and resourceful.
The course is an excellent overview of cancer epidemiology.
This is a very good intro course into cancer epidemiology and will give you a broad understanding/background in the subject material
